title: Flawed fine print no surprise to the experts
text:
"But in almost every other facet of life – from mortgage choice to superannuation – we are all expected to be experts in highly complex areas.

"Anything goes as long as you disclose has been the way these complicated financial products have been regulated. It's left up to the consumer, it's all their fault if something goes wrong."

The Australian Securities and Investments Commission said its focus would now shift to forcing companies to police their products before they were let loose on consumers, requiring them to dump those that are too complex and prune fine print "sludge".

Ms Thorp's research was among the case studies, collected over a decade, contained in the ASIC report, published on Monday night.

Her research found superannuation dashboards – intended to provide a simple snapshot summary of a super product on a fund's website – were found to be "vulnerable to manipulation".

"The experiment found people don't always do what we expect, nor act in their best interest."

That's down to how the information is presented, she said. The experiment found that the information was presented in a way where people were choosing to "avoid all their eggs being in one basket" when assessing whether to select investments in stocks, property or other assets.

But when investing in super, consumers needed to think more about risk and return, Ms Thorp said. When the one-page form was changed to encourage that kind of choice framework, consumers then changed their behaviour.

Advertisement

"Disclosure needs to be tested not so much as if they understand but how they apply the disclosed information in their decision-making," Ms Thorp said.

The report also found that advisers disclosing a conflict of interest – traditionally relied on as a key safeguard to warn consumers – sometimes had the opposite effect.

The report revealed research that found some customers "may place an even higher degree of trust in the salesperson, as a result of the salesperson's candidness".

Then there's the "likeability" of the adviser.

"We know that people will often judge the quality of advice on the likeability of advisers," Ms Guthrie said.

The peak representative body for the $1.4 trillion profit-to-member funds which includes industry funds and public-sector funds and corporate (company staff) funds, said the ASIC report reinforced the need for default super funds.

"This report reinforces what we have known for a long time: that the default safety net in super is vital to protecting consumers. Disclosure is necessary but insufficient when it comes to protecting consumers and improving their retirement outcomes," Australian Institute of Superannuation Trustees chief Eva Scheerlinck said.
description: Finally. That's the response from experts to a report by the corporate regulator that found more disclosure, more fine print that no one reads, has failed to protect investors.
